column4: 买！ 虽然是dlc地狱，但是真正的月厨会点下面的那个绿色按钮的，是吧？ ----------------------------------------------------------------------- 说一下，有人说无法调分辨率，在下载界面直接点开始游戏是没有配置工具的。 要在游戏库里点开始游戏，然后会出现两个选项，下面的就是配置工具，可以调各类选项，游戏里是没有设置的。  个人感觉移植得还可以，就是键位仍然是ps4的，插上x1手柄竟然是让我按B确认。

我去，永久降价到24，对之前的玩家太不友好了！！  没有MOD的饥荒，是不幸福的。 游戏强推，最好是设置房间密码，因为时不时会有一堆脑残智障来烧你家 想要快速上手的同学们可以去创意工坊下载个齐天大圣的mod，晚上的火眼金睛会让你不怕黑暗，并且火烧不死 还有地上洞穴mod，不用下地穴了，很好很强势 最好有一两个好基友一起玩，要不怎么叫TOGETHER呢？ 吐槽一下龙蝇，尼玛，2W多血，也就算了，刷新的地图龙蝇还跟一大堆子海象巢穴在一起。到了冬天简直是血雨腥风 顺便说一句，代码这东西能不用，就不用，否则就失去了游戏的意义

游戏画面很爆炸，画质也不错，就是整体色调有些艳丽，我觉得看久了会有点累眼 刚刚玩的时候感觉有毒，完全停不下来，再各个地方穿梭的感觉很棒，特别享受景物从身边飞驰而过 游戏背景还有风格还是有一点点脱离现代时间的，我感觉我完全带入不进去啊！ 不知道为什么，打了几个城市，几个基地后，我打开地图，发现还有很多这种千篇一律的，我有点乏了 剧情什么的已经吸引不了我了。 那一天我关了游戏后，就再也没有开过它，我想，以后也应该不会再开了 我对它简直又爱又恨啊，可惜只能推荐或者不推荐，我权衡了一下可玩度，剧情，体验，还是给个不推荐吧。 当然，喜欢“突突突突突突突突突突”的玩家千万不要错过

column3: Not going to be one of my longest reviews
column4: but here it is. It's basically TNO
column5: but more of it. There music
column6: voice acting
column7: and sound in general is damn near perfect. The action and violence abounds
column8: although it's bordering on the edge of a cover shooter more than an action shooter
column9: until you get thoroughly upgraded. The story is as solid as TNO and some set pieces clearly pay homage to (and make you feel like you are in another version of) other FPS like Fallout
column10: DOOM
column11: and even The Old Blood
column12: weirdly.   I haven't upgraded my hardware since before TNO came out
column13: and I was able to run this on Ultra with only one or two frame drops the whole way through. That being said
column14: it seems like a lot of people have issues
column15: so I guess if it runs for you it runs well at least.  I do have some complaints but they aren't enough to push it negative:  Collectibles are way more annoying in this than in TNO. There's more of them and they require a lot more hunting and backtracking to get. It would have helped a lot if Star Cards dropped off enemies until you collected them all instead of just being more clutter hidden away. Also the other collectibles seem less outlined than loot laying around
column16: even when you're looking right at one it can be hard to see. It detracted from the game for me because the collectibles in TNO were part of the flavor and world building
column17: and rarely had to break the flow of the game much to get them
column18: whereas here you can spend a good chunk of your time just trying to find the letters and whatnot. It's a shame to see one of my favorite parts of TNO take a solid step backwards.  Second would be the underuse of the bigger cast of characters
column19: while relying on just a handful of the honestly not that interesting ones. It would have been great to see the other characters used outside of the free roaming hub section.  Third would be the auto-pickup radius is too small. If it was doubled it would probably feel about right. As it was
column20: I found myself constantly passing back and forth over piles of bodies mashing the E button trying to pick up the supplies I needed.  If any of those 3 things sound like dealbreakers to you
column21: then consider yourself warned
column22: but the game overall is still a solid A from me. With a few improvements it could have been GOTY contender again but sadly
column23: it falls short of that in the end.

column5: but then the rest of it was intense (that's an understatement really). With Before the Storm I was able to get into the story right away. I like that there are no super powers this time. It makes it easier to relate to the characters. To my surprise I'm truly enjoying playing Chloe
column6: guess it's just fun being a rebel teenager? Going back to Chloe's house felt like visiting an old friend. My feelings for Rachel Amber changed many times during the first chapter and I loved how the story gave me these emotional nudges. I'm in no hurry to play the final chapters
column7: because I want to be in the right mood when I do. My review of this game is obviously affected by my feelings about Life is Strange
column8: but I would recommend it for all wannabe rebels out there.

column3: I have not played games like Stellaris before
column4: so this review is mostly for people like me who might be pondering whether it's worth getting. I bought Stellaris over a year ago
column5: launched it a couple of times
column6: but the controls didn't seem very intuitive and the game felt quite overwhelming. I decided I would play it later and this week I finally did.  I chose an avian species
column7: Yondar
column8: that looked kind and majestetic. I imagined they thought themselves a little bit better than others and probably dreamt of enslaving another species. With that in mind they started exploring space. Unfortunately
column9: this far they've only met species with more advanced systems than theirs. They managed to build an alien zoo
column10: but it -and the whole planet- was lost when some mutated creatures killed off the colony. Now Yondars are on a quest for Alien Specimen Procurement
column11: which I think is the perfect thing to highlight their superiority.  At the moment I'm having problems with pirates raiding them
column12: because I have neglected building their fleet and used resources wastefully. There's no doubt I have made a ton of strategic mistakes and because of that I don't except Yondars to thrive very long. I plan to check some game guides before starting over with another species. Overall
column13: it's been a fun journey this far (I confess
column14: I'm hooked) and that's why I would recommend Stellaris
column15: especially when on sale.

Games like this are hard to judge on face value alone. When you take more common
column4: action oriented titles
column5: it can be easier to tell from just a minute or two of uninterrupted gameplay footage if a game is going to be worth your time or not. But slower paced
column6: narrative focused titles
column7: like Whispering Willows
column8: are considerably harder to figure out from just viewing a short trailer. Games like this are driven by their quality of narrative and puzzle design. Does the crisp and whimsical imagery evident in WW’s screenshots affirm a similarly elegant literary and brain teasing experience? Unfortunately
column9: no
column10: not even close. But Whispering Willows is still an endearing first effort by fledgling studio Night Light Interactive
column11: even with the game’s numerous flaws. In fact
column12: it’s more what the game  doesn’t  try to do that is most disheartening.  I’ll begin with the most egregious error this game makes: the quality of narrative. The story is thus: young Elena’s father has gone missing
column13: and has been for some time. After waking from a particularly vivid nightmare of her father being held captive by  something
column14: she races to an old
column15: decrepit mansion
column16: of which her father is the groundskeeper. She soon meets the ghost of her ancestor
column17: who teaches her of her heritage
column18: and of her innate ability to leave her body and walk the earth as a spirit
column19: allowing her to commune with the ghosts of those who have yet to pass. What follows is a supernatural tale of loss
column20: deceit and the darkness that festers within.   In truth
column21: the narrative plays out like cross between a darker Goosebumps tale with bits of Clive Barker’s grotesque imagery. This is partly due to the art style; it just doesn’t convey feelings of foreboding and fearfulness that I believe the narrative wants to. Worse
column22: the story takes virtually no risks. But what really hurts the experience is the quality of the dialogue. Throughout the adventure
column23: you will speak with the deceased
column24: and often be asked to find items of importance to them to progress through the story. The dialogue that occurs here is just
column25: well… the best thing I can call it would be
column26: “serviceable”. The dialogue is so often uninspired and plain that it would keep me from really caring for any of the characters’ plights.   I feel I’ve spoken enough on the negatives of the narrative
column27: so let’s move on to the disappointment of the game’s main mechanic
column28: your spirit form
column29: and the weak puzzle design dependent on it. The lack of pluralization is not a mistake
column30: Whispering Willows’ mechanic of Elena’s spirit form most often offers only a single type of puzzle throughout the game. You will come across locked doors
column31: and you will either need to pick up a poorly hidden key or flip a switch. Usually
column32: this means that there is a finely carved
column33: perfectly square hole in the wall or ceiling near to you for your spirit form to slink through. Do so
column34: and there will be a bright blue glowing  thing  for you to interact with. This interaction opens the door. This is how nearly every “puzzle” in WW plays out. I can only think of a handful of individual puzzles that do not play out in the same way
column35: though they themselves were no more complex than filling a hole or playing Simon Says with a moveable object. The simple puzzle design falls in line with the game’s progression; it’s largely linear
column36: with nary a handful of instances where you will have to seek out an item outside of the area you’re already in. Even then
column37: though
column38: the item’s location is always spelled out for you
column39: so this is really no more than a mode of adding longevity to this short adventure. And it  is  short. In total
column40: I completed the game in under three hours.  Whew
column41: that was a lot of negativity. How about we move on to the more positive aspects of Willows? Speaking purely of the in-game graphics and art style
column42: my opinion is decidedly varied. On one hand
column43: the environments that you explore never amount to anything special
column44: and much like the dialogue
column45: they are content with remaining largely serviceable. The same can be said for the few human characters in-game
column48: look oddly plain. This is in stark contrast to my favorite portion of the game
column49: the ghost designs. Their visages reflect how they died
column50: and their appearances range from the grotesque to cringe inducing. Their designs are absolutely phenomenal
column51: and it’s evident where the best of the artistic talent went in the creation of this game. The same can be said for Elena’s own spirit form
column52: whose flowing hair and glowing visage look fantastic
column53: especially in the light of the full moon in outdoor areas.   While the dialogue between yourself and haunting spirits itself does the overall narrative little favor
column54: your interactions with the ghosts of the mansion’s grounds are enriched by the previously mentioned collectible notes scattered along your path throughout the game. Each is one of several diary entries left by the formerly living
column55: and each tells a tale of their final days. While few of them are terribly unique in their subject matter
column56: finding that final piece of each story provided me a greater driving force for playing than the main narrative itself.   As negative as this review has been
column57: the greatest fault I can levy against this game is not what it does poorly
column58: but rather in what it does not even attempt to do. Given all that has already been done with a similar ability in other games
column59: why is Elena’s spirit walking ability as limited as it is? The game is content with delivering only the most lackluster and plain variation possible. And the dialogue... in an adventure title such as this
column60: gameplay often takes a backseat to the narrative. Only
column62: both aspects are severely limited in their designs. If the sole gameplay mechanic is to be as limited as it is
column63: why was the dialogue not given greater love
column64: to compensate? The game is so filled with potential
column66: this potential appears as though it’s so near to bubbling to the surface
column67: only to be pushed back down below by weak interactions and the umpteenth recycled door “puzzle”.  I did not hate my time with Whispering Willows. Though admittedly
column68: my want to love it so completely has perhaps made me more critical of its faults. I’ll leave it at this: Whispering Willows
column70: is content with providing only an unenthusiastic effort on its part. For every glimmer of something fresh and unique
column71: of which there are a few
column72: Willows buries it under less-than-uninspired dialogue and consistently recycled puzzle design. I beat the game
column74: in under three hours. By the end
column75: my only thoughts were on what  could have been
column76: had this game taken just a little more risk
column77: rather than on my final moments with Elena. There just isn’t enough content or thought put into Whispering Willows to make it  fully  recommendable.   6.5/10

column7: and little else. But oddly enough

column17: and serve only to manipulate your stats
column18: which themselves are completely  ir relevant until the very end. The  actual  narrative is only touched on at specific points after a certain number of “turns” have passed. Only
column19: these points
column20: while not necessarily “jumping around”
column21: speak of events that never happened
column22: of people and groups that you
column23: the player
column24: likely never have heard of prior
column25: and attempts to piece together a story using only the beginning
column26: several middle points
column27: and end

column30: or several
column31: branching narratives
column32: like a  real  CYOA. In retrospect

column45: short as they are

column3: Given the charming
column4: cutesy art and some emphasis on riding creatures
column5: my initial thoughts were that  So Many Me  would be akin to Nintendo’s favorite kid-friendly pink puffball
column6: Kirby
column7: with some added puzzle elements to round out the package. And in some ways
column8: I was right. The aforementioned art design is adorable and inviting
column9: and riding the animals
column10: (especially the dino)
column11: brought back fond memories of riding Rick the Hamster or Coo the Owl from Kirby’s Dreamland. But this is where the similarities to Nintendo’s friendliest series end
column12: and for the better
column13: in many respects.  So Many Me ’s emphasis on expansive
column14: challenging puzzles and platforming prowess provides an exceptionally demanding cerebral and dexterous experience that I never expected. And I absolutely adored every moment of it.  From the moment you boot up the game
column15: you’re assaulted by one of the cutest and charming art styles this side of  Kirby’s Epic Yarn
column16: and from the get-go
column17: the bubbly movement of the characters and the world they inhabit put a big smile on my face. But as adorable as they are
column18: the graphics disguise the true nature of  So Many Me . It’s  extremely  challenging. It’s easy to reach the end of each level
column19: sure
column20: but by  only  doing so
column21: you’re missing out on more than half of what the game has to offer. Of the main worlds
column22: (of which there are four
column23: each with their own specific gimmicks) reaching the end
column24: as I said
column25: is easy to do. Rather than simple exercises in moving rightwards whilst jumping over small pits
column26: levels range from small to expansive networks filled with traps and tricks for you decipher your way around. Most are avoidable
column27: unless you aim to collect the three collectibles in each stage. Each level hides a costume
column28: an extra Me
column29: and an artifact. And these aren’t hidden in the traditional sense; you’ll be able to see them
column30: plain as day
column31: as well as the seemingly impossible-to-bypass trickery blocking your path to each. This is where the  true  game lies. The puzzles between you and those delectable collectibles range from the small and simple to the overly complex and level-wide. Even once you’ve figured out  what  you’re supposed to do
column32: it’s an entirely different matter pulling it all off without screwing up.   And you will mess up. A big part of what makes these often complex puzzle layouts complex
column33: is that in congruence with an often demanding level of dexterity on your part
column34: you will have to carefully manage the use of your me’s which provide you with stepping stones
column35: switch presses
column36: bounce pads and other varying abilities dependent on world. Mess up the proper order of tasks even once
column37: and it’s back to step one. It’s as much about strategy as it is making each clean jump. I often found myself stuck on figuring out several of the more complex puzzles in the game for nearly a half hour or more
column38: since there are often so many pieces you can experiment with
column39: but it made the satisfaction of  finally  getting that artifact or costume so much sweeter. But most importantly
column40: the collectibles  matter . Besides the obvious use of having extra mes or new costumes (which you can use to uniquely dress up each and every me)
column41: artifacts are used to purchase perks
column42: which range from the purely aesthetic to the all-but-necessary in reaching certain collectibles. There are no superfluous “good job!” collectibles here
column43: and when the game  really  makes you earn each and every one
column44: it truly feels like an achievement.  Luckily
column45: checkpoints are forgiving
column46: and so long as you remain in the level
column47: enemies do not respawn outside of specific instances
column48: even after you fall into a spike pit a half dozen times. And thankfully
column49: you’re never asked to find every collectible in a single go; you’re free to try again at any time
column50: as each level is easily selected from the game’s pause menu. Allow me to iterate: Once you find a me in a given level
column53: it’s yours. Once you kill an enemy
column56: as long as you remain in the level. This all leads to levels feeling more like contained little worlds
column58: each with their own sense of progression
column60: where smaller puzzles act as cogs leading into a whole. Further variation in mechanics come in the form of your creatures
column62: and the boss battles ending each world. These are generally of no real concern once you have their given patterns down
column63: and it’s only until the final boss that you might have any real trouble
column64: as the difficulty is dramatically increased here from what you’ve faced previously. But again
column65: it’s all a matter of pattern memorization and careful movement.  For anyone more inclined toward the purely platformer aspect of  So Many Me
column66: in addition to the four main worlds and end boss levels
column67: the developers have kindly opted to include a fifth bonus world
column68: filled almost entirely with exceptionally challenging platformance gauntlets. Many of these courses demand perfection on the part of the player to succeed
column69: even more so than some of the later levels in the standard worlds
column70: and each offers two elusive artifacts just out of reach for all but the most skilled platformer aficionados. With no checkpoints to speak of
column71: a few skirt the line of frustration that lies between the game’s mechanics and your own inability to succeed
column72: though it typically lies closer to the latter. I cannot stress how challenging some these completely optional segments are
column73: and along with the larger puzzles provide some of the most satisfying moments in the game to best
column74: especially with both artifact pieces in tow.   So Many Me  is brilliant. If it wasn’t clear in the preceding paragraphs
column75: know now that I adored the entire experience. Despite looking more kid friendly in nature

column3: Of the Sands of Time trilogy
column4: Warrior Within is easily the most controversial of the bunch. Forgoing the whimsical  Nights of Arabia  theme of the much beloved Sands of Time
column5: Warrior Within employs a much darker tone
column6: replacing melodic instrumentals with blood pumping metal music
column7: and an emperor’s majestic castle with that of some dreadful thing from a metal album cover. Gone
column8: too
column9: is the storybook hero known only as the Prince
column10: who is now a curse spewing
column11: murder loving psychopath
column12: easy to anger and eager to slice open stomachs. Understandably
column13: not all took a liking to the new Prince of Persia
column14: and many either wrote it off or gave up after dying in the first 10 minutes
column15: all while cursing the monsters at Ubisoft who would dare slight their beloved franchise so vehemently. I am ashamed to admit that while I did not join in the publisher bashing those many years prior
column16: I  did  assume the many fans’ angers as legitimate. After having neglected the franchise for many years since the original
column17: I have finally played through the trilogy’s entirety. Lo and behold
column18: my judgment is thus: Warrior Within is the best of the Prince of Persia trilogy
column19: and one of the most challenging and equally frustrating and rewarding titles I have ever had the pleasure of besting.  Where its predecessor
column20: The Sands of Time
column21: relied on linear level progression
column22: a typically gradually increasing difficulty
column23: and relatively basic (and easy) combat
column24: Warrior Within features a (sort of) open world
column25: varied weapons of combat
column26: and enemies that will break your face if you’re not perfect. It also features a higher emphasis on combat than its predecessor
column27: and  some of the most frustrating puzzle and enemy design than any other game I’ve played in years. But understand what I mean by that. Warrior Within
column28: for the entire duration
column29: never held my hand. The moment I felt I had a handle on how to deal with an enemy type
column30: a brand new exploding
column31: near unavoidable dog animal thing would be introduced. Obviously
column32: it wasn’t always an exploding dog thing
column33: but you get the point. WW is never easy or gradual in its difficulty. It’s not typically fair
column34: either
column35: but it also never felt impossible
column36: and that’s what made it fantastic. For comparison
column37: while playing Demon’s Souls
column38: I always felt in control of what I was doing
column39: and typically only died if I was quick to run into a room before checking for barriers to hide behind
column40: traps or tricky enemies in the shadows. WW will put you in a room and deal death unto you until you learn to deal with it
column41: and the experience became infinitely rewarding upon besting said situations.   Puzzles don’t quite follow the same degree of difficulty that the combat does
column42: but the challenge comes in unintended traversal. By puzzles
column43: I refer to the Prince of Persia’s method of travel; running along walls
column44: sliding down ropes and hanging banners
column45: and avoiding the many
column46: many spikes and saw blades inexplicably sticking out of walls. The open world aspect of Warrior Within allows you to re-visit any portion of the island that you’ve previously visited
column47: and you don’t necessarily have to follow the same paths. However
column48: the design of these pathways are sometimes altered by the game’s events
column50: traversal in any way different from the standard is a challenge in and of itself
column51: as the developers clearly did not design these paths to be easily followed backwards (or forwards
column53: as you will have to do. Worse yet
column55: especially those bastard dogs I mentioned previously
column56: the ones that can take half of your health. If this sounds frustrating to you
column57: it should. But by the point you should even be considering doing anything like this
column58: you will have already become invested in beating down this seemingly personal hell that the developers have created just for you.  I won’t divulge any of my secrets for passing through Warrior Within
column60: I would recommend any and all to refrain from guides as much as possible throughout (except for the collectibles
column61: you’ll need a guide for those). Warrior Within is a truly brutal and often unfair achievement in sadistic game design. It’s also one of my most satisfying completions in the entirety of my gaming career. Nearly every instance of combat in this title will chew on your face and kick you in your?????until you  really  learn to play it. The learning curve can be steep and unfair
column62: and you will want to quit. Don’t. There are no tricks to Warrior Within
column64: and hopefully a share of dumb luck
column65: will see you succeed. What faults it has

Road Not Taken is a roguelike puzzle game about surviving life’s surprises . But life is so often content with stagnation and repetition
column4: offering what seems the same grind over and over and over
column5: soon only occasionally taunting with the glimmer of something new. But that’s just the way of things; everything new becomes old
column6: in time. Eventually
column7: new  just begins to run out. RNT follows a similar cycle; in the beginning
column8: discovering all these new things and how you can change and adapt them to your uses is exciting and intoxicating. But soon enough
column9: the  new  is exhausted
column10: and with it
column11: the allure of the prospect of new discoveries waiting just behind each locked gate. RTN is profusely entertaining up until you realize this point has come
column12: but even after then
column13: its unique and challenging formula saves it for a time
column14: despite other issues
column15: both glaring and minute.  RNT plays off its theme of “life’s little mysteries” remarkably well in its gameplay. As the town’s new ranger
column16: you’re tasked in each of your years with rescuing the children lost to the woods during each winter’s storm. To deliver them safely
column17: you’ll have to guide each to any of the waiting mothers
column18: wherever they may be
column19: using your limited amount of energy in carrying the odds and ends populating each level. The greatest joy had in this game also provides its greatest challenge; the discovering of new items and creatures that can both greatly hinder or assist you in your search. There’s a surprising amount of variety in the number of ways things can interact
column20: with many even able to change into new forms entirely
column21: given the proper combination. You’ll quickly begin filling your travel book with all manner of creatures and their respective “recipes”. Eventually
column22: puzzles that seemed impossible in the beginning are soon found to have only been so due to your own ignorance of some combination relevant to the situation.  But here’s the rub
column23: and it’s one that eventually hinders all games of this sort. After a while

column26: if even that. There’s a handful of items and creatures that are exceptionally common
column27: changing in relation to your years. In my playthroughs
column28: those handfuls have been identical. The aforementioned variety in items and enemies becomes less so when the same few common assets are used ad nauseam
column29: which is a shame
column30: given the inventiveness of some of the lesser used pieces.  In between winters
column31: your time is spent in the town you call home. Here
column32: you can take your hard earned coins
column33: rice
column34: berries
column35: etc
column36: and trade them for townsfolk’s friendship
column37: a la the story of  Rainbow Fish . In return

column41: but the greater are earned through repeat visits. They
column42: along with the tradeables found in the forest
column43: make up the other half of the Roguelike formula
column44: namely the part that you lose upon death. Make too many mistakes

column56: and which one is most willing to marry you

column8: I’ve not found it (at least on Steam). A word to all: Ignore the obvious warning signs of a budget price and lackluster art;  SPA  is a surprising amount of fun
column9: and offers a stupendous metroidvania adventure
column10: despite a few small flaws along the way.  What surprised me most about  SPA  wasn’t the notably tight controls nor the exceptionally entertaining notion of controlling a panda with a katana. No
column11: what surprised me was the sheer size of the level layouts
column12: and the many paths therein. Levels are typically huge
column13: and often reach deep into the ground and high into the clouds. While there are plenty of collectibles and upgrades waiting to be discovered
column14: the emphasis on exploration and pathfinding is based more on your abilities and equipment as you find them
column15: rather than on hidden paths or destructible walls. Meaning
column16: the passage to a new upgrade is usually only blocked by a wall higher than your current jump
column17: or a door requiring a key that you can’t reach for a similar reason. Repeat exploration is encouraged
column18: and most levels feature  something  new to do after each new ability is earned.   Combat is also surprisingly prevalent and entertaining
column19: but then
column20: the prospect of a sword wielding panda is an entertainment in its own right.  SPA  features a leveling system
column21: powered by hidden caches of points and killing enemies alike. Typical upgrades are standard fare
column22: but by finding special orbs in each level
column23: your armor and weapons can be upgraded
column24: and changed in appearance as a result. Although I never became bored with the combat
column25: exploring and re-exploring the same levels over again  could  have felt more tedious without the consistent rewards of combat or in seeking out hidden caches.   Not all is well
column26: however
column27: and while minor
column28: there are several notable flaws that hamper the experience. Boss encounters typically carry a massive disparity in difficulty from the rest of the adventuring
column29: due to enormous health bars and attacks equally both powerful and annoyingly difficult to avoid. The large levels
column30: while a joy to run around in and explore
column31: have no map system to fall back on
column32: and so path finding relies solely on memory. When looking for each and every collectible and upgrade
column33: that fact becomes irritating quickly
column34: especially on the more vertical levels. Worse
column35: there is no “percentage complete” function
column36: and so those missing odds and ends could literally be hidden in any level
column37: and there’d be no solid clue as to which.   Regardless of listed faults
column38: SPA  is an absolute delight. While the unenthusiastic art design would normally all but promise a similar quality of gameplay
column39: SPA  provides a metroidvania styled adventure similar to what you would expect of a higher priced title. Given the quality
column40: this game  could  have been sold at a standard $10 price point. For a standard asking rate of only $4
column41: it’s an absolute steal.

After roughly 8 hours I'm not done with the game yet but I feel like I've seen enough to write a review. The game was very fun at first but the more I played the more tedious it got. I will still try to finish it but man is it taxing right now.  Overall the game looks and plays a bit like a crossover between Serious Sam and Minecraft. I picked up the game mostly because of it's graphics and I still dig them.  You spend most of your time mowing down hordes of enemies with various melee weapons and firearms in changing environments. The variety of weapons and enemies is big
column4: which is a plus. The maps are fairly big as well
column5: sometimes too big
column6: but mostly pretty linear. The rest of the time you search for ressources to craft weapons
column7: items and armour with. I never ran out of anything so far because the ressources are really plentiful. It took me a while to aquire good firearms but that didn't bother me that much since melee seems to be relevant throughout the whole game. Sadly that is all there is to do and it gets old pretty quickly. From the first level to the one I'm currently at the gameplay didn't change one bit. Moreover the game is just so damn easy
column8: even later on. Yes
column9: a couple of the bosses are no pushovers unlike the rest of the enemies and the traps are a hassle but everything else is a stroll through the park. Taking damage is no problem anyways since you have enough healing items to provide a whole army with it. There is some sort of hunger system as well but as of yet I really don't get what the point of it is. You find enough food in the game to solve world hunger so the system might as well not be there. Meanwhile the story is nonexistent. You're a guy who is stuck on some islands and kills everything that moves. The RPG elements are ok but I think you level up too quickly. I read somewhere that the level cap is 65 and I'm currently at level 62 so I will probably reach max level before finishing the playthrough. That makes me also wonder why there is a need for a new game +.  All in all I just can't recommend the game right now. My opinion could of course change once I am done with the game but at the moment I doubt that it will.  Edit 1: Level 65 most certainly is the max level
column10: reached it way before the last level. Another thing that speaks for the game is that it runs very steady. No crashes and almost no bugs
column11: Jumping is a bit choppy and some enemies in the later levels refused to die but that's about it.  TL;DR: Nice graphics

column16: a bat with a jack o'lantern head that emits light. She can then interact with shadows in several ways to stun a target
column17: stabilize a movable object
column18: cure a possessed creature
column19: control a creature to borrow its abilities
column20: or dive into the shadow of an object to either climb slopes
column21: or to pass unharmed through obstacles.  The game itself is fairly linear
column22: and a level mostly consists of walking from the start point to an unspecified target location
column23: while fighting possessed creatures
column24: or solving puzzles with different kinds of shadow magic. There are some optional collectible objects in the form of journey entries or other documents
column25: but they are usually easy to find.  Once you have figured out the basic mechanics
column26: most fights so far are rather straightforward: Lock the light source to the enemy
column27: throw a Shadow Knife into its shadow to stun it
column28: then jump once or more on its shadow to cure it. Things become slightly more difficult when confronting multiple enemies at the same time
column29: and there was at least one considerably more difficult boss fight. But since Schatte gains experience / levels
column30: there's no reason to be concerned about a too high difficulty.  The puzzles are usually simple
column31: but it still can take a while or some experimentation to find the solution.   What I didn't like about the game:   There's no options menu
column32: except for the unity dialog at launch
column33: which at least allows to choose a resolution / quality setting
column34: and look up / change the controls.   Many parts of the first levels look very bland. But it gets better later.   Maybe it's just me
column35: but at the beginning I had a hard time understanding some of the basic mechanics. In particular
column36: I didn't understand which terms refer to buttons / keys (e.g.  Shadow Stamp )
column37: and which terms refer to actions associated with those (e.g.  Shadow Bind )
column38: and that I was supposed to tap a certain button / key.   There's only a single save state
column39: and the game automatically saves at certain points. That means if you accidentally select  Start  instead of  Continue  in the main menu
column40: you have to play certain parts of the game again. While there is a Chapter select option
column41: it doesn't allow to select single levels within this chapter
column42: and you cannot return to the main menu once you have entered this sub-menu; so if you select this
column43: you either have to replay the whole chapter
column44: or force-quit the game (I haven't tried this
column45: so do this at your own risk!) Fortunately
column46: character level and collectibles are not reset when replaying a chapter.   You can die at a certain part in the tutorial level  before  the game saves for the first time. This can easily happen if you didn't understand some of the instructions
column47: and when this happens you have to replay the whole tutorial with the not-completely-skippable dialogs.  While those issues can lead to some initial frustration
column48: the game plays fine once you know how to deal with those / are familiar with the basic mechanics.   All in all
column49: I'd recommend the game if...   ...you're looking for a small relaxing indie game with a witch theme
column50: and some unique mechanics   ...you don't mind the lack of sound options
column51: or in-game graphics / control settings   ...you are confident in your ability to navigate menues w/o accidentally selecting options that reset some of your level progress   ...you can handle some potential initial frustration (ymmv
column52: maybe I just didn't pay enough attention)   ...you don't need achievements or trading cards

column3: Note: This review is based on singleplayer mode   MRS SNAKE is a take on Flying Snake
column4: which in turn is a 3D version of the original Snake games.  The gameplay is simple: You are a snake in a restricted 3D area in space
column5: and you have to eat items to get longer. You receive damage over time
column6: or if you hit obstacles
column7: and the only way to stay alive is to keep eating items
column8: which replenishes some health. The longer you become
column9: the more difficult it is to avoid crashing into yourself. If you die
column10: you get a score based on your length.  While the concept is simple
column11: it is also a rather unique game
column12: and well-executed
column13: making it a fun little score chaser:   The growth rate is tuned well
column14: and you don't spend too much time moving through an empty area   The starvation mechanic forces you to take risks and make quick decisions
column15: instead of encouraging boring
column16: but more safe strategies   The close-up 3rd person view with transparent snake head shows just enough that the gameplay is interesting
column17: and obstacles never block your view in an awkward way   Using the camera to look for nearby items while not crashing into your tail is a neat skill to improve   The arcade-style runs are open-ended
column18: and there's always room for self-improvement. Unlike the original snake games
column19: you won't run into a situation where you cannot move anymore unless you are  really  good   The minimalist and geometrically-themed look fits the game perfectly
column20: w/o making it more performance-heavy than necessary. I particularly like the way it looks when parts of your tail move in different directions   Gamepad support seems decent: No XInput required
column21: and a large list of gamepads is supported. The developer seems to be active and has already improved some things based on user feedback. And even if a gamepad isn't detected correctly
column22: there's a text file in the game folder which I assume can be modified to make it work   While the game is probably designed to be played with an analog stick
column23: I slightly prefer to use my D-pad for quicker turns
column24: so an analog input device is by no means required.  The specified high GPU requirements seem to assume a certain number of players
column25: but for singleplayer or only a few players
column26: it can be played with a much older GPU (performance seems to scale with the number of views).  I like the music
column27: which reminds me of old experimental synthesizer stuff
column28: but this game is just perfect for listening to your own music. Fortunately
column29: music and sound effects can be enabled / disabled separately.  While I haven't played the (local) multiplayer mode
column30: I would assume that it is fun: The game is plug and play
column31: simple to learn
column32: supports up to 8 players via split-screen
column33: and has decent gamepad support. I also heard there are multiplayer-exclusive power-ups that you can use against each other.   Conclusion  While the game is simple
column34: I find it quite enjoyable once in a while
column35: particularly when I want to listen to some music
column36: or if I feel like playing an avoid 'em up type of game
column37: but want something more relaxing than a bullet hell shoot 'em up. It's well executed
column38: it's one of a kind
column39: the developer seems to respond to feedback
column40: it's cheap
column41: plug and play
column42: has good gamepad support
column43: and I assume multiplayer is fun.  My only complaint is that there are no online leaderboards
column44: and gameplay could be a bit more varied in singleplayer mode. Also
column45: online multiplayer would be a nice option.

column3: This is
column4: hands down
column5: one of my favorite bullet hell games so far!  The player can choose between 4 ships with different shot patterns and stats. There are also 2 unlockable ships that seem to have the same stats as existing ships.  The ship controls in this vertical shoot 'em up are highly responsive
column6: with a Touhou-style focus/slow button that allows for precise movement. Aside from the main shot
column7: there are secondary weapons that can be useful in certain situations
column8: and the Baryon Laser
column9: which is explained below.  The main gameplay can be summed up as following: - shoot enemies to fill up the Baryon Laser gauge - when the gauge is full
column10: activate the Baryon Laser - this turns enemies and bullets into items that fill the Grabuster gauge when collected - after some time
column11: you enter Grabuster mode
column12: which lasts until the gauge depletes  In Grabuster mode (or Gravastar
column13: the translation is inconsistent)
column14: the ship is surrounded by what looks like a small black hole
column15: and turns into a weapon that can be moved quickly across the screen
column16: while damaging everything it touches. The above cycle is tied into the score system
column17: and you can maximize your score by planning when to activate the Baryon Laser
column18: when to pick up items that fill those gauges
column19: and by prioritizing certain targets over others in Grabuster mode (-> increase the multiplier before destroying larger enemies that are worth more points).  Getting hit activates a shield for a few seconds
column20: and prevents you from losing a life at the cost of some Baryon Laser energy
column21: if you have enough. However
column22: this is risky and worse than using the gauge for the Baryon Laser
column23: so it's more of a safeguard with a major drawback.  The patterns in this game are very basic
column24: consisting of aimed and static shots / bullet clusters
column25: which sometimes rotate or expand slightly. So it's less about memorizing fancy bullet patterns
column26: and more about navigating quickly through static bullet patterns while avoiding or guiding aimed shots
column27: and trying not to get cornered by dense bullet curtains. The colorful bullets can be easily distinguished from the background
column28: with some rare exceptions. To make things more interesting
column29: the game encourages horizontal movement by making the stage slightly wider than the play area
column30: and with visible or hidden ground targets that provide items or collectibles.  The bosses are basically floating platforms with a main core
column31: and attack turrets as optional targets. While the bosses themselves aren't very unique
column32: the fights are somewhat interesting because the player has the option to either play it safe
column33: or destroy all turrets
column34: which will spawn sets of stronger turrets
column35: and allows for a higher score.  With 12 stages
column36: the game is quite long for an arcade shoot 'em up
column37: and there's an entire second loop with more difficult stage variants in Arcade mode
column38: while Story mode offers plenty of dialog
column39: and some lengthy unlockable endings.  The story centers on a squad of 4 pilots
column40: who have to face a fearful enemy
column41: and deal with a conspiracy
column42: which is complicated by the role and background of each pilot
column43: and by some outsiders that become involved later. There are some anime cliches
column44: along with US / Hollywood cliches
column45: and some explicit language
column46: reminding me a bit of Black Lagoon. ;) I generally liked the story
column47: especially for setting the mood or making me care about the characters
column48: though sometimes it was a bit hard to follow (mediocre translation / alternate drawing style in endings)
column50: or overly dramatic.  Apart from Story and Arcade mode
column51: there's also a practice and a caravan mode. If that's not enough
column52: a DLC with 4 additional stages / 2 loops and another story mode can be purchased.  What makes this game great IMO is the unique gameplay which ... just feels right as a whole
column53: just like the gameplay in Eschatos
column55: Trouble Witches or Murasaki. It's hard to explain
column56: so I'd recommend to just try the demo. ;) In addition
column57: I'm completely addicted to the soundtrack
column58: which was the reason why I bought the game in the first place. :)   However
column59: the game has some considerable flaws: - no graphic settings besides window / fullscreen (only 1280x720) - either vsync with noticable input delay
column60: or no vsync with noticable screen tearing
column61: no in-game vsync option - w/o vsync
column62: game may set the framerate to the monitor refresh rate (e.g. can run at 144 instead of 60 fps) - mediocre English translation - small main game area in case of non-widescreen monitor - in rare cases
column63: the game freezes for a moment - no replays - 8 achievements seem to be unobtainable(?) - the Start button on a gamepad cannot be remapped  While many of those should be fixed
column64: it doesn't affect my experience too much: Window mode works for me
column65: I don't mind the screen tearing or changing the monitor refresh rate
column66: I'm usually not able to get all achievements in a bullet hell game anyway
column67: and the freezes are rare and hardly affect gameplay. What bothers me most is that the main game occupies only a small area of my non-widescreen monitor
column68: but it's still highly playable thanks to the excellent bullet visibility
column69: except for higher difficulty levels where it can become a pain.  It's also noteworthy that the game has unlimited continues
column70: and using a continue does not reset the score. There's a reward for avoiding death
column71: but there doesn't seem to be a strong penalty for dying a lot compared to dying once during a boss fight
column72: and I wouldn't be surprised if this could be slightly exploited. I'm not an expert
column74: and I don't know how much potential for a boring exploit there is. If this bothers someone
column75: there's at least the option to refuse to continue
column76: and ignore scores that don't have a zero at the end.

Disclaimer:  A number of players reported a bug where they can't play the game
column4: because they get a black screen when trying to start a new game. I didn't encounter this bug
column5: but if you buy the game
column6: I recommend to check if there's a problem
column7: so you can refund the game withing 2 weeks of purchase if necessary.    Squirbs is a platformer with an interesting twist: You control two characters at the same time
column8: which will respond equally to your inputs. So if you jump
column9: both characters jump
column10: and if you move right
column11: both characters move to the right. For each character
column12: there is a crystal shard in each level
column13: and you need to get very close to them with both characters at the same time to finish a level.  The levels can feature some simple puzzle elements like crates or switches
column14: but usually the actual puzzle involves planning a path for both characters
column15: moving one character freely while the other one is blocked by a wall
column16: preventing one character from jumping by pressing <jump> while that character (but not the other one) is in the air
column17: planning when to best switch your focus between both characters
column18: and so on. Later levels introduce teleporters
column19: surfaces that influence your movement
column20: and other interesting level elements.  The controls are responsive
column21: and you move / stop as soon as you press or release a button or keyboard key. Jump height can be controlled precisely by releasing the <jump> button/key sooner or later. The only thing I don't like here is that you can't jump while holding <down>
column22: but I only remember one level where that became relevant
column23: and I beat it after adapting my strategy.  So
column24: is this a good game? Well
column25: I greatly enjoyed this game
column26: and would definitely answer that with a 'yes' for me! :)  However
column27: there are two important things to consider:   1) The platforming in this game becomes very technical / difficult starting after world 1 of 4
column28: requiring you to make precise inputs in order to avoid a mistake that means instant death
column29: so it becomes comparable to Super Robot Jump Jump
column30: Super Meat Boy
column31: I Wanna Be The Guy
column32: the bonus levels in the Escape Goat games
column33: or Kaizo Mario World. However
column34: there are no hidden traps
column35: and each level consists of a single screen and takes less than a minute (often only a few seconds) if you don't make any mistakes
column36: so it's still very much doable for ambitious players.  2) The game is a bit unpolished: Gamepads are supported via XInput
column37: but you can't navigate the options menu with a gamepad
column38: or use it to skip a story screen that you will only see once / the intro screen. Also
column39: if you have a smaller resolution (I think the game is designed with 1080p in mind)
column40: the downscaling doesn't look as nice as it could
column41: and button icons or numbers are sometimes hard to recognize. Another thing I noticed is that physics don't seem to be 100% deterministic on a slower PC
column42: so it can happen that one character is a pixel further to the right than the other character after walking half a screen width
column43: despite a symmetrical level layout. However
column44: this was only rarely a cause for failing
column45: so it was mostly negligible for me. I was also a bit disappointed that there was no ending
column46: but at least there's some satisfaction thanks to the achievements for completing it.   Some other reviewers claim that it becomes just mindless trial and error after some point. I can not confirm this: For example
column47: the wall jump mechanics that can be found later are implemented in a clever way where you vertically jump if you press the jump button (no directional buttons required) while adjacent to a wall. A smart player will make use of the option to wall jump without moving the other character
column48: while a player that relies on mindless trial and error will fail in many situations where such subtleties are relevant for success. So thinking is definitely rewarded. ;)   ------------------------------------------  If you like frustratingly hard games and can look past those flaws
column49: or like to try out games with an innovative concept
column50: I think it's definitely worth it.  Also
column51: if you waver because of the high difficulty
column52: you can still consider picking it up and just play world 1 when the game is at a discount that justifies something between 30 minutes and an hour of playtime.

column3: 100% Orange Juice is a fantastic online boardgame for up to 4 players
column4: with characters from the developer's other games (Suguri/Sora series
column5: QP/Xmas Shooting series
column6: Flying Red Barrel
column7: 200% Mixed Juice).  The game has a silly over-the-top humor
column8: with seagulls that fly across the board to attack other players
column9: a hamster-like character that speaks in a foreign language and likes to rob others
column10: and a female Santa Claus with rabbit ears who fends off attackers by hitting them with her present bag. In short: It's a lot of fun
column11: unless you somehow hate anime
column12: or cute characters.  What I like the most about this game (aside from the humor) is its perfect balance between strategical depth and RNG: On one hand
column13: analyzing the parameters over which the player has control can be quite interesting
column14: and you can spend a lot of time with meta analysis
column15: if you like doing this. On the other hand
column16: there are a lot of things that are outside the player's control. While you can gain a bit of an edge with smart decisions
column17: you're still at the mercy of the RNG. Put together
column18: this makes for a game that can be enjoyable for both strategists and casual players
column19: without being too onesided. And if you like roguelikes
column20: you're probably happy to read that the game can throw you in a lot of different situations
column21: where you have to improvise with the "items" (cards) on your hand in creative ways
column22: or make an educated guess.  At its core
column23: the game is quite simple: Players take turns
column24: and roll a D6 to move forward on the board
column25: and the panel they land on determines if they gain or lose stars
column26: draw a card
column27: or if other things happen. Players can also battle other players
column28: allowing them to steal their stars and gain points if they KO them. To win
column29: players need to level up a certain number of times by landing on a player home panel with the required stars or battle points.  While this may sound a bit boring
column30: there's much more beyond this. First of all
column31: the game has a very interesting deck mechanic
column32: where players create or choose a deck of 10 cards before the start of a game. However
column33: the cards from all players are shuffled into a common deck. So
column34: to build an efficient deck
column35: you can't just add cards that are good for your character; you also have to consider how bad (or good) it is if other players draw those cards
column36: which
column37: btw.
column38: is the far more likely outcome with 4 players. The cast of characters is quite diverse
column39: with each character having different stats
column40: an exclusive hyper card that (usually) only this character can draw
column41: and sometimes a passive ability. The character diversity results in very different playing styles or card synergies
column42: which keeps the game fresh.  The battle system is simple
column43: yet elegant: The challenger rolls a D6 for attack
column44: and the challenged player chooses to defend or evade
column45: before rolling a D6. Then roles swap
column46: and the challenged player is allowed to counterattack. The rolls are modified by the character stats
column48: and sometimes other factors. Since character stats are very small numbers
column49: it's possible to estimate the risk of challenging another player quite well
column50: except for potential cards that the other player may play.  Now
column51: the battle system is a bit more than just a gimmick thrown into the game for some forced chaotic interaction: Some characters are good attackers
column53: or star gatherers (which is a bit of an oversimplification). In addition
column54: characters pose more or less of a threat depending on their HP
column58: and how much they need your stars. Sometimes it's safer to attack someone
column59: because passing them would allow them to attack first. Sometimes
column61: because it allows you to stop on their panel. And sometimes you don't want to pass another player
column62: because you know the other player will attack you to land on your panel.  There's a lot more to say about the game mechanics
column65: and the many ways cards and active events have an impact on the game. Figuring out how to build a good deck for certain characters
column66: or to play them well can be an interesting
column69: there's only so much that a player can influence: While the game has a lot of depth
column70: playing well is often countered by bad luck
column71: and vice-versa. If you expect that the best player wins
column72: this is not the game for you. If you enjoy meta analysis
column73: and are pleased to win slightly more often if you play well
column74: you might enjoy this game. And if you just want to have some silly fun while chatting with other players
column75: without having to think too much about the deeper aspects
column76: this game has you covered.   While the game has a singleplayer mode
column77: I mostly played it to unlock some things
column79: and to try out things offline. The AI is very limited: It gets most of the basic things right
column81: and makes poor risk management decisions. In the singleplayer campaign
column82: the difficulty setting determines how much the AI player rolls are rigged (the final boss even makes a comment about this ^_^). You can get some enjoyment out of singleplayer mode
column83: but it probably won't last long.   The developers / publishers seem to care a lot about the game
column84: are active on the community boards
column85: and keep updating the game with bug fixes
column87: or seasonal events with special rules and obtainable cosmetics
column88: and so on.  My experience while playing with strangers has been good -- particularly during seasonal events -- and finding new friends to play with isn't difficult with this community.  Regarding DLC: There is a lot of DLC
column89: but IMO the only essential DLCs are the two card packs. The (Japanese) voice packs are worth it as QoL features
column90: if you care about this. For new players
column91: the base game already has a lot of characters (18
column92: some of which have to be unlocked). So the character DLCs aren't necessary
column93: and I exclusively played base game characters for a long time
column94: even though I owned some of the DLC characters (which often are a bit more difficult to play for someone who is new to the game). Note that two character DLCs (Breaker & Witch Pack) add a new campaign
column96: in case this is important for you. While I ended up buying all DLC
column97: I did it because I wanted it
column98: and not because I felt I needed it to enjoy the game
column99: and because I wanted to support the developer / publisher.  The only two bad things I can think of off the top of my head (ignoring minor issues) are: 1) The manual is outdated
column101: and contains a crucial mistake that caused me to misunderstand one of the core mechanics. But there's a good beginner's guide on Steam
column102: and the game has a link to an extensive wiki. 2) It takes some time to unlock all cards and characters. I personally don't care about the latter
column103: but I found it a bit annoying that I couldn't just freely build my deck for a tank character
column104: until I unlocked several rare HP recovery cards
column105: which are more or less mandatory for such a character.

God game
Here's finally my review of Hyperrogue
column4: probably my favorite game on Steam! :)  In a nutshell
column5: Hyperrogue can be described as a minimalist tactical roguelike in the hyperbolic plane. So
column6: what does that mean
column7: specifically?  First of all
column8: it's a minimalist roguelike
column9: and there is no equipment
column10: and no items except for Orbs (basically spells) which are often activated upon pick up. Hyperrogue is turn- and grid-based
column11: and combat rules are simple: Every attack is guaranteed to hit
column12: and is usually deadly - for monsters as well as for the player. As a roguelike
column13: it has permadeath. To avoid accidental player deaths
column14: the game prevents you from performing actions that immediately result in your death
column15: though there's a hardcore mode for the more confident players. Basically
column16: the goal is to collect as much treasure as possible in different game modes
column17: either in total
column18: or for a specific type of treasure. In addition
column19: there are some very challenging quests (most of which would be easy in a Euclidean setting)
column20: and a lot of achievements and leaderboard categories.  The game is easy to pick up
column21: but difficult to master
column22: and is suitable for anyone from casual players to science nerds or hardcore players. However
column23: be warned that there are no difficulty modes
column24: so it can be frustrating
column25: and you won't be able to unlock certain game modes (chaos mode
column26: Orb of Yendor challenge mode) unless you're very ambitious. Also
column27: you have to be a top player to legally get 100% achievements.  About the more unusual aspect: Hyperrogue is the only elaborate game that I know which features hyperbolic geometry
column28: a type of non-Euclidean geometry! To give a short explanation for this weird kind of geometry
column29: I start with the other (more intuitive) type of non-Euclidean geometry
column30: elliptic geometry: 2-dimensional elliptic geometry is simply the surface of a sphere. So if inhabitants of Earth couldn't move up or down
column31: they'd be living in an elliptic plane. As a grid
column32: we could combine regular hexagons and pentagons in a way that 2 hexagons and 1 pentagon meet in a vertex
column33: which gives us a "football". Euclidean geometry is the "normal" geometry we're used to
column34: and the Euclidean plane is simply a flat surface. For a grid we can use regular hexagons. Now hyperbolic geometry is kind of special: While we can combine regular hexagons and pentagons to get a (positively curved) plane
column35: a possible grid for hyperbolic geometry consists of regular hexagons and heptagons
column36: making it "negatively curved". If we try to do that in the Euclidean world we are living in
column37: we get a wrinkled surface resembling the structure of corals
column38: and it gets more extreme the larger the structure becomes
column39: to the point where our Euclidean universe can't handle the non-Euclidean madness. However
column40: Hyperrogue uses another method of representation (see Poincaré disk model)
column41: the same which you see in M. C. Escher's  Circle Limit  patterns: In this kind of representation
column42: cells appear smaller the further away they are from the center
column43: and quickly become too small to display on the screen. But if we travel to those cells
column44: we'll see they're the same size as other cells. :)  An interesting property of hyperbolic geometry is that space extends more quickly
column45: and you could fit the surface area of Earth in a circle with a comparably small radius. As a consequence
column47: and then walking back in the approximately (but not exactly) same direction will likely cause you to end up in an entirely different place
column48: so it's very easy to get lost! Another consequence is that escaping pursuers is easier: Head towards a seemingly small gap between two pursuers
column49: and that gap will turn out to be larger than expected! Also
column50: there is no exact equivalent to "parallels" in a Euclidean geometry
column51: and if your pursuers try to walk in parallel
column52: the outer ones have to travel a larger distance
column54: conveniently lining up for you to defeat them one-by-one. On the other hand
column55: running into unexplored territory means a lot of cells are quickly revealed
column56: potentially containing lots of monsters.  Another interesting aspect is that you can have a hub land with quick access to many infinitely large lands without using teleporters
column57: or a waypoint system. :) The world of Hyperrogue consists of such hub lands
column58: and lots of other different lands with their own kind of treasure. Each land has some unique mechanics
column60: often requiring an entirely different approach. For example
column61: the starting land - Icy land - has heat-based mechanics
column62: there's a land where the ground vanishes beneath your feet
column63: and there's another (cellular automaton-based) land where the walls have a life of their own
column64: and you have to be careful not to get trapped.  The game is being actively developed
column65: and new lands and game modes are released with major updates: Currently
column66: there are 37 regular and 4 hub lands
column67: which is a lot more than the first Steam release had! Also
column69: and there's probably always a friendly person who will help you if you are stuck
column71: or just want to discuss several aspects of the game. Also
column72: the developer has been very open to suggestions
column73: and is eager to fix reported bugs
column74: and keep the leaderboards "clean" in case there are obvious cheaters. A drawback is that major updates often introduce a considerable number of bugs
column75: but with the excellent bug fix support they usually don't persist long after being reported.  The game currently has the following modes:   The standard mode where you can collect treasure to unlock more lands
column76: and attempt several quests   Collecting a certain amount of treasure unlocks the respective land in the pure tactics mode
column77: where you can try to get highscores in individual lands w/o using items or monsters from other lands   There's a cheat mode that also gives you access to map editor tools
column78: and lets you experiment with hyperbolic patterns.    In the random pattern mode
column79: lands appear with unusual floor/wall patterns. This mode is not well-balanced
column80: but it can lead to some interesting and fun situations   The Euclidean mode features Euclidean versions of the basic lands
column81: which is interesting if you want to find out which impact the unusual geometry has on the game   You can print a sheet to create a warped paper model of a scene from the game
column82: and there's a mode where the game simulates such a paper model (remember what I mentioned about corals
column83: and trying to embed the hyperbolic plane in our Euclidean world?)   The shmup mode removes grid restrictions and is real-time
column84: allowing for local coop with up to 4 players (I didn't try this mode much)   The heptagonal mode allows you to explore the world of Hyperrogue using a different grid that is a bit simpler (only heptagons)
column85: but where the hyperbolic aspect is much stronger   Collecting a lot of treasure unlocks the chaos mode
column86: where lands are more dense and w/o walls / hub lands
column87: leading to some interesting interactions   For very ambitious players who manage to clear the Orb of Yendor or Prince(ss) quest
column88: there are related quest modes. Especially the OoY challenge mode is noteworthy!   The soundtrack is released under a Creative Commons license
column89: and the game comes with the source code
column90: in case you care about that.  If you're unsure about buying: You can download a slightly older
column91: free version of the game (along with the source code) from the developer's homepage
column92: which should give you a good impression what the game has to offer. However
column93: don't forget that it neither has leaderboards
column95: which are IMhO important aspects of the playing experience. The price is IMO far below the game's worth
column96: but that's a very subjective point; still
column97: I think the price has always been very fair given how unique the game is
column98: and how well it is supported.

以下是我对这游戏的真实感想：        1.首先感谢送我这个游戏的小可爱！像这种既能玩奇迹暖暖又能玩恐怖游戏的人不多了！显然她不知道我不敢玩这类型游戏，因为我只敢玩玩少女游戏。        2.画面，音效都很不错，就是小男孩有点面瘫。场景啊材质感啊什么的都很棒。        3.操作键什么的有点多，毕竟我只能把换装游戏玩好的手残。、        4.杀死第一个人后，我疯了，我竟然开始期待后面的人是怎么死的，不过杀老人还是有点点罪恶感        5.玩到现在，地图就是小恶魔的家，妈的家好大。我觉得跟个迷宫一样。。好累        6.杀人效果不错，血腥，爽！爽！哈哈哈        7.警察弱鸡，剧情一般般，反正就是个杀杀杀的游戏        8.这游戏我是死拉着我表弟陪我玩的，尽管他才上五年级，但是我觉得他这么小，应该见多点世面。   我不是害怕，真的          9.这游戏我给8/10分，不错不错，   顺便求点胆子大的好友呀嘿嘿嘿

column3: 推荐mod下载： （nass的故事模式mod下载），覆盖了ea本身的故事模式，这样城镇里的每个居民都会有自主意识了，娶妻，生子，结婚，打架，出轨，离婚，自己找工作等等，这样玩起来比较有意思。  （杂物mod）爱装饰房子的人的天堂，一堆零散的东西，使整个屋子更有情调，更加有生活的气息，大到超级大的投影仪电视，小到一瓶瓶的红酒，一块块蛋糕，还有女生最喜欢的包包，鞋子，有各种裙子贴图的衣柜，简直是小公主的生活。  （动作盒子mod）适合做M3剧场版的童鞋们，可以让小人摆出各种各样的动作，配合你想要表达的剧情..  （嘿咻补丁）这个我就不多说了。。好像有5种xxoo的动作。。是会动的you~跟看黄片一样，同时有冒险嘿咻，嘿咻，尝试怀孕等选项，从此以后再也不用盯着被子看他们嘿咻了！！  http://game.3987.com/xiazai/6231.html   （R18各种补丁）洗澡时去除马赛克，打架去烟雾。男生女生身体上必要物件的补丁。。房中术，，可以申请嫖娼做鸡什么的，18岁以下就不要下了。 {LINK REMOVED}  http://pan.baidu.com/s/1b34Sn8   密码 kvu8 （超级电脑）没有超级电脑的M3根咸鱼有什么区别！这个功能太多了，太多太多了，我感觉我才用了40％不到，这个推荐必装  还有一个功能蛮全面的帖子： http://bbs.3dmgame.com/thread-4390774-1-1.html   剩余几个mod，游民，贴吧，搜一搜都能找到，我就不附上链接了，欢迎大家补充   还想吐槽一下，资料片真贵！！前前后后买的资料片花了快1000了，结果夏季特惠，每个资料片才24，我的内心是崩溃的。。。。‘真特么坑啊！

游戏画面很爆炸，画质也不错，就是整体色调有些艳丽，我觉得看久了会有点累眼 刚刚玩的时候感觉有毒，完全停不下来，再各个地方穿梭的感觉很棒，特别享受景物从身边飞驰而过 游戏背景还有风格还是有一点点脱离现代时间的，我感觉我完全带入不进去啊！ 不知道为什么，打了几个城市，几个基地后，我打开地图，发现还有很多这种千篇一律的，我有点乏了 剧情什么的已经吸引不了我了。 那一天我关了游戏后，就再也没有开过它，我想，以后也应该不会再开了 我对它简直又爱又恨啊，可惜只能推荐或者不推荐，我权衡了一下可玩度，剧情，体验，还是给个不推荐吧。 当然，喜欢“突突突突突突突突突突”的玩家千万不要错过

I've spent 4.5 hours straight in this game since I got home from work. I love it. It is very simple and doesn't have a TON of depth yet. But there is something about the scale and loneliness that immerses me like few other games have. I spent a majority of my play time just flying my ship around my starting world from outpost to outpost exploring and spent 20 minutes happily lost in a cave system
column4: before jet packing out of a ravine that happily came out on the backside of a hill overlooking my crashed ship. Discovering new creatures is also a treat XD. I found some really cute little dog thingys and some bigger fish cows among others. Check my profile for screenshots. The promised features coming in future updates really have me excited to see where this game is headed.  There are a couple cons however. I do wish I had more control over my ship when I was flying in atmosphere. I also wish there was a map feature (that really anybody with access to tech this advanced would logically have) that would log previously seen and visited locations along a planets surface. There are also some performance issues however I don't think these will be a problem for long. The game does not like alt-tabbing. I haven't had it crash on me yet
column5: but lots of other people are reporting crashing before even being able to play.

Great game overall!

column3: I am only saying no on recommending it because of the ports many many flaws. Chrono Trigger is an amazing game
column4: but with so many flaws I'm voting no it hopes that Square will fix it or at the very least stop giving us the horrible mobile ports.  Here's a list of Stuff they need to fix. - Graphics filter makes this beautiful game just look bad. - Tiles in the overmap need to realligned correctly. The fact that you can see the individual squares is just unacceptable. - In-game overlay and HUD needs to be revamped. It is literally the ios overlay. Needs to be updated to suit the PC. - The overlay and HUD need to show PC buttons and not Controller buttons in the menu. I don't even have a controller for my PC. - Needs to have actual Graphics Options instead of just the resolution. - The game needs to have some serious optimization. There is no reason for this old of a game to have hiccups and FPS drops. Especially since it's an ios port. - Sprite Filtering needs to have an option to be turned off. - Fix the Wait option for battles. The Wait option literally says "Take your time to choose items and fight strategically" you cannot do this because despite the Wait option being marked the monsters constantly attack.  and for the love of god please give us back the original sprites.  Chrono Trigger is one of my most favorite games. I am very sad it was treated like this. If they do fix the game I would happily change this to a million times recommend. Even in the state that it's in I would have to say pick it up and enjoy the story and extra dungeons they added into it.  If you can get past the issues I mentioned you will not regret playing this amazing game.

column3: If there's one thing i could say about the game it's that this would undoubtedly be perfect for the iOS as it works wonderfully as a time killing card battle game and i could see many other's being able to get into it even more strongly on that platform. While the tutorial doesn't do well to explain the mechanics of the game very clearly i was able to easily figure my way around having played many card games of a similar nature in the past so found myself able to soar through my playthrough with fair ease on normal mode and overall found this one quite enjoyable!  One of my favourite features was getting to talk to the girl's and getting to know them individually
column4: over the course of the game you can unlock 'topics' and interact with them during certain periods using 10 AP
column5: When exiting the game there seems to be special skits where you can see some of the girls from other teams or otherwise interacting or in some cases saying an ending message by their lonesome as was the case of a certain heroine.  Other than that it turns out my new kitten really loves this game and puts her paws up on the side of my laptop to watch which is just too precious~ The ost is wonderful and the work the artists did on all the available characters is something to really be admired.

column3: Romanticizing Pastoral Life ― Stardew Valley starts with a relatively cut and dry plot that throws you in the middle of an inherited farm. The basic loop of the game starts out with you cleaning up the farm
column4: planting crops and trying to figure out what the town is about. That in itself was enough and hit home for me personally
column5: as I too am privy to the ideals of escapism to get away and live off the 'fat of the land'. The game so far feels like a simple game about farming but soon adds another layer ― keeping up friendships and trying to fix up the town to its past glory. But it doesn't stop there it keeps going with each passing season things change peoples personalities evolve and open up along the way.   You find a mine
column6: you discover fishing ― all of which are repetitive mundane tasks to say the least but this game's sleep and seasonal cycle doesn't let you dwell on one thing for too long and nudges you towards improvement. But of-course you have choice ― you can attend that festival or let it go
column7: keep farming
column8: fishing or mining everyday or potentially have a more balanced experience. The game very rarely forces your hand into doing something rather it nudges and suggests.   I'm still working my way through the game but
column9: if you want to decompress and chill out
column10: give it a try
column11: you will know within a loop of a day or two
column12: if this is your cup of tea or not.

column6: I've played Boss Monster a few times before this electronic version showed up on Kickstarter. I do not own the mobile version.  Let me start by saying I own a Surface Pro 3
column7: a Windows 8.1 tablet. I thought having a digital copy of this would make it fun to play on the go. The problem is the port has some critical bugs they need to fix. Story time...  The major game bug I had is with touch devices
column8: after a while the game loses focus. When you're tapping the screen you're actually clicking behind the game window. When you finally Alt+Tab to the desktop you'll see all these programs open because you've been clicking your shortcuts and items on your desktop. This bug is terrible
column9: and would happen every 3-5 minutes without fail
column10: when not using a mouse. I would have to hit the Windows button a few times to bring up the start menu
column11: then click the program in the task bar
column12: or I would have to hook up a keyboard and forgo the ease of using the Surface as a tablet to recover the game.  This bug seemed to happen in fullscreen

column14: sound effect volume
column15: game speed

column30: I have to win 40 games... that means I have to win 40 games on each device I own because the save game isn't transferred between my devices or carried over after I reformat. :(  Lastly
column31: some game design choices are weird. When using a touch devices you have to double tap everything to activate
column32: when using a mouse it is a single click. Also the Halt button seems like a waste. There is no reason for the Halt button. The game should show you the 3 buttons
column33: Pass All
