column3: I purchased Overcooked: Gourmet Edition during a Steam sale. Overall
column4: it is a fun local co-op game but it REALLY does need online multiplayer; especially for those days when no one in the household wants to be player two. Completing a kitchen by yourself with three stars is doable but it's both more enjoyable & less strenuous with more people (obviously). Definitely recommend playing with a controller vs. keyboard. Also
column5: I would have liked to have seen additional recipe combinations & kitchen layouts. I would say it currently offers less than what it could offer. I still recommend this game but am not sure it's worth the regular price without online multiplayer.

column3: Bayonetta is an over the top Hack and Slash game produced by the famous dev Platinum Games    Story  The story in this game is highly non nonsensical
column4: but it spins around the old battle between the Umbra Witches
column5: who represent Dark; and the Lumen Sages
column6: who represent light. The protagonist
column7: the witch Bayonetta
column8: is cough in between the conflict and also amid a sinister plot to resurrect an ancient divine being   Game play  Game play is a very good hack and slash game
column9: somehow similar to the Devil May Cry series. As Bayonetta
column10: you can jump
column11: shoot infinite shots with your gun
column12: you have a punch and a kick button
column13: and finally you can dodge
column14: which is an important mechanic
column15: since dodging is related to the power of witch time (slow motion). You must combine those many kind of attacks to perform combos and defeat the enemies.    Unlockables  As you progress in the game
column16: you will unlock a lot of stuff
column17: including a few weapons
column18: many strange items and some other stuff. When you beat the game
column19: you will unlock some costumes and characters
column20: along with a cool gallery mode.  So good to see all these Unlockables things given to you as you play the game
column21: instead of just being sold as DLC
column22: which is what happens in most games now-a-days…   The Bad Side  This game is very good
column23: but make no mistake: it’s also filled with bull schit. The worst are by far the quick time events: You are sitting and watching some cool and provocative cut scene
column24: when suddenly the game shows on the screen that you might press quickly “up + jump”. You have like 2 seconds to do so
column25: otherwise you are insta killed! Those insta kill quick time event are unfortunately all over the place in this game
column26: and this breaks the flow of the game
column27: as you are constantly dying for stupid reasons. Take that away and you would have a perfect game.   Game is a very good Slasher Overall    I give it a 4.5/5.0

column3: Very good game! You will really enjoy it even if you are not an anime fan
column4: like myself.  Hell
column5: you might enjoy it even if you dont like fighting games at all!    Story  The story mode is actually pretty dull and boring
column6: mostly because its too long and takes more than 12 hours to complete. Im not gonna spoil the story
column7: but it spins around the arrival of a new Android threat in the Dragon Ball universe. The story is divided into 3 arcs: the first one is centered around Goku and the "good guys". The Second arc is around Frieza and the "bad guys"
column8: like Cell. And the Final Arc is around the androids. Once you complete the story mode you will unlock the boss as a playable character..   Gameplay  Generally speaking
column9: the gameplay reminds me of a faster and more agressive version of Marvel vs Capcom. The gameplay in this game is divided into many layers. The first layer if for mashers: you can perform basic combos by just mashing the attack buttons. However
column10: those combos are not well optimized and deal less damage. If you really want to go deep into the combo system and stop mashing
column11: you will discover that the true good and damaging combos are very complex and demand many hours of practice in the training mode. The game also has lots of other mechanics that need to be know and mastered befor you can consider yourself a descent player. The learning curse is really high and the skill gap between a good player and a bad one is enormous.   Visuals  The visuals in this game are astonishing! Through a new cell shading technique
column12: ArcSystems managed to make 3d characters and environments look EXACTLY like the anime
column13: if not better! The final product is a 3d fighting game that looks like 2d hand drawn manga. Really and impressive sight to behold!   Optimization  Game is very well optimized and runs fine in most PCs. As a side note
column14: I was able to run the game even without a proper graphics card
column15: using only my onboard GPU.   Overall
column16: this game kicks azz and totally overthoned Marvel vs Crapcom as the new fast paced tag fighter.    I give it 4.8/5/0

column3: This game is a stunningly beautiful and breathtaking adventure through various underwater environments. The game utilizes the full spectrum of colors across multiple environments
column4: from bright coral reefs to the dark deep sea. It's a delightful surprise to see what new regions and new sealife you will find next. But what I found most impressive about this game though
column5: was its ability to deliver an interesting story and tell the history of the environment simply through the environment itself. In the beginning
column6: you are just thrown underwater with a quick tutorial of controls but no story is revealed until you go searching for it yourself. The art direction is fantastic in that you learn so much about the background of where you are based on the observations and interactions of your surroundings. This encourages exploration as there's always something fascinating and magical to find through your journey. The game is short (roughly just an hour or two for one playthrough)
column7: but if you appreciate pretty open-world games
column8: like to explore and find things
column9: looking for a calming but stimulating experience
column10: or even if you've just always wanted to scuba dive
column11: I definitely recommend this game!

column3: There are basically two things you should know about this game: first
column4: is it a good game; second
column5: is it a good port.  To the first question
column6: Zork Nemesis is among the best first-person point-and-click games of its era
column7: and maybe my favourite outside Cyan Worlds' Myst/Riven. The plot involves you entering an ancient
column8: run-down temple and learning about the plight of four great alchemists who have been trapped in a state of purgatory by an evil presence called Nemesis. Of course
column9: like many great adventure games
column10: things are not as simple as they seem.  It is a great game with tough but fair difficulty
column11: no arbitrary deaths
column12: a great little story
column13: excellent cutscene direction
column14: and really interesting and varied locations. If you take notes you should be able to beat the game without restoring to a guide
column15: but there are also many guides online if you need to cheat. It is well worth the $5.99. The graphics are pre-rendered backgrounds with live action FMV playing on top of them
column16: which at the time was very exciting and cutting edge. Also very nice music and sound effects
column17: they really made the most of the 3 or 4 CDs the game shipped on.   Compared with other games in the genre
column18: it has a darker and more sinister tone. It's not quite horror
column19: but at times it's close: for example
column20: one segment involves you decapitating a cadaver with a guillotine and hooking up the severed head to electrodes. This is not the light-hearted comedy of the traditional Zork games
column21: although there are jokes here and there.  To the second question
column22: I think the quality of the port is mixed. First
column23: the game was released in two versions: Windows 95 and DOS. This is the DOS version
column24: emulated through DOSBOX. There are no achievements
column25: trading cards
column26: gamepad controls
column27: graphical settings
column28: etc. Moreover
column29: the DOS version requires you to use keyboard commands to save (Ctrl+S)
column30: load (Ctrl+R)
column31: exit (Ctrl+Q)
column32: and set options (Ctrl+P) because there are no menus. Please read the manual before you play to help with this. There are two minor technical issues -- some slight sound crackling
column33: and mouse sensitivity is way too high. The bulk of the game is navigated through panning your field of view with the mouse
column34: and so high mouse sensitivity makes it difficult to control. You can set it to a lower sensitivity in the preferences
column35: but even on the lowest setting
column36: it is too sensitive. This appears to be a the  GOG.com  version
column37: which also suffered from these issues.   There is also a question of the game holding up. It runs at 640x480; the FMV overlays are highly compressed
column38: interlaced
column39: low resolution video. Some of the game's beautiful visual designs look blurry or low detail because of the resolution
column40: and there are a handful of puzzles where you must be very very precise with the mouse because click targets are quite small. This is definitely not modernized or ready for 2017
column41: so I would recommend you be sure that you can handle something feeling dated before you jump in.   I highly recommend the game. The playtime listed above is until completion on a replay; someone playing for the first time without a guide would be looking at probably 10-12 hours

column6: I suggest you begin with RealMyst Masterpiece Edition and go on from there (maybe buy the Cyan Complete Pack if they update that to include Myst 3 and 4.). The review below contains spoilers for Myst as well as descriptions of the worlds contained in this game.  For everyone else
column7: I think a good review of this game should answer two questions for you: 1) Is this game worth playing if you're a fan of the series? 2) Is the port / release of the game good? (The answers to those questions below the break)  In general I think Myst 4 remains a good game and I would recommend playing it if you are a fan of the series. I do think it is weaker than the first three games
column8: but I think it still justifies the time that it asks of you. I grew up playing Myst and Riven and just recently got the opportunity to complete Myst 3: Exile
column9: but had never touched this game before now. I have to admit that my first impression of the game was not good. The current release is full-screen only and 4:3 resolutions only
column10: so my initial reaction was disappointment in seeing the excellent art design stretched. There is also a design decision that annoyed me up-front and never got better: the transitions between screens are slow
column11: the mouse cursor is sluggish
column12: and in an effort to make the mouse cursor feel more like a hand there are a bunch of animations for the cursor as you mouse over hot spots. This decision makes the entire game feel molasses slow. So
column13: right off the bat
column14: the game had a strike against it.  The plot of the game is that Atrus has summoned you to his home to ask you to visit his sons
column15: Sirrus and Achenar
column16: in the ages he has imprisoned them in
column17: to determine if they have reformed and should be let out. While visiting him
column18: he is called away momentarily. Then
column19: all hell breaks loose. The game plays out over a hub world (Tomahna)
column20: two prison ages which can be completed in either order (Spire and Haven)
column21: and a finale age (Serenia). The ages are quite large and the game itself feels longer than Myst or Exile for sure. The hub world is beautiful and serves as a good introduction to the game. The two prison ages I liked a lot less -- Spire
column22: specifically
column23: is a beautiful dark prison tower. Is that what Ubisoft Montreal was going for? Yes. But the fact that I do not want to spend time in the age is a bad thing. Haven is more hospitable but suffers from being truly enormous and having in my opinion too many nodes to navigate. I spent more time mapping than solving any real puzzles. The final area
column24: Serenia
column25: is beautiful and enjoyable.  Like the earlier three games
column26: the world design is gorgeous. Sights are frequently breathtaking. I posted a few dozen screenshots for those interested. The engine allows for full 3D looking and every scene is crammed full of layers
column27: animations
column28: and movement. This really does feel like the culmination of the old node-based navigation adventure game. Like the earlier three games

column31: is maybe a little too insane -- the game gives you all the information you need to solve it
column32: but knowing how to apply that information requires a leap I think even seasoned adventure players wouldn't make. The rest of the puzzles in the game seem to me to be basically solveable given effort and the right set of skills. I found Haven disappointing
column33: because the puzzles felt like busywork -- only the climactic puzzle felt like the kind of spatial/logical puzzle Myst is otherwise known for

column3: I'd offer a weak recommendation to Sethian: if you read the game's premise and it's interesting to you
column4: I'm confident you will get something out of the game. But the execution is something less than the premise.  The pitch of the game is that you are a xeno-linguist who has landed on an alien planet and is interacting with a computer system guarding the planet. Unfortunately
column5: both the input keyboard and the responses the computer gives are in the Sethian language. The idea is that by using some basic clues and asking questions
column6: you can eventually learn something about the structure and words of the language and make sense of the planet you're on. You're presented a computer with 100 symbols for words and a handful of punctuation symbols
column7: and initially at least it feels like you're going to have a pretty meaty game with lots of exploration. You take out some sheets of paper to take notes so you can get the hang of the language.  Where the game fails to live up to its premise is that after a few simple questions about the language
column8: you're essentially granted a half-complete dictionary
column9: and those words that are not included are not part of the game. So the 100-odd symbols you see are actually perhaps 20-odd symbols in total. And shortly after this
column10: you learn about a particular event in Sethian's history
column11: at which point your character is only interested in this event and the computer is only willing to talk about the event. I think this is a problem because although this is clever and interesting
column12: you're left wanting to know more about the language you're using and the events that have taken place in the world.  Compounding this problem
column13: your character writes his (or her) thoughts in a journal
column14: but this journal includes the character's interpretations of the computer's answers and thoughts about what to ask next. So for the bulk of the game's runtime
column15: you're literally just inputting what the journal tells you to input and then reading the computer's response in the journal.  After a while you get to the game's first ending. The ending is clearly a "bad" ending
column16: and it's implied there's more you can do. If you embark down the path to the second ending
column17: the journal stops updating
column18: and so you're expected to get things right on your own. This is something closer to the promise the game offers
column19: but this segment of the game is a few short questions where the computer bombards you with words whose meanings you don't know. But the computer is very rigid in both how it expects you to ask questions and what it is willing to answer
column20: so mostly you're fumbling until you get the exact right question to advance linearly. The second ending is more upbeat.  I read all the Steam discussions and guides surrounding the game and external posts on other websites to get a sense of whether other players got more meaning out of Sethian than I did. The answer is... sort of. People are clearly asking questions and interpreting things
column21: but there isn't much there to go on. So I checked the Kickstarter for the game
column22: and it strikes me that what was promised was something a bit larger in scope than what was delivered. The author put a lot of thought into why the language would have the symbols it does
column23: but then doesn't use half of them. Also
column24: I decided to dive through the file structure of the game to see if there was any hidden content -- I was surprised to find out that the game is essentially a series of jpgs
column25: numbered linearly. Knowing that the content was stored this way internally made it clear to me that there isn't a hidden layer to the game beyond what I'd seen. I think maybe this is a case where the developer's ambition (to combine his learning of Chinese
column26: interest in linguistics
column27: interest in old mathematics and philosophy
column28: and desire to develop a game) outstripped his ability (developing a more flexible parser
column29: producing enough content
column30: world design for a broader world).  This review sounds pretty negative
column31: so let me wrap up by saying: If you're interested in a game about learning an alien language and using that language to uncover clues about the alien civilization
column32: Sethian is an interesting and worthwhile stab at that. But I think if you're really interested in the premise
column33: in the end you'll wish there was more.

column3: I write this review for people who have already played Myst and Riven and want to know whether to continue playing the series. If you have not played these two games
column4: I suggest you begin with RealMyst Masterpiece Edition and go on from there (maybe buy the Cyan Complete Pack if they update that to include Myst 3 and 4.). I have light spoilers recapping elements from the first two games below.  For everyone else
column5: I think a good review of this game should answer two questions for you: 1) Is this game worth playing if you're a fan of the series? 2) Is the port / release of the game good? (The answers to those questions below the break)  To the first question
column6: yes
column7: I believe Myst 3 is worth playing if you're a fan of the series. I grew up playing Myst and Riven and had dabbled with Myst 3: Exile in the past
column8: but never completed it. On the whole I think this is an inspired spiritual sequel to Myst and Riven. I say spiritual sequel because besides the obvious difference that the game was not developed by Cyan Worlds
column9: the plot takes place in a sort of between-space where events and characters from Myst/Riven are mentioned but in general all the events of this game have no real bearing on Myst 4 or 5. The game involves a character called Saavedro
column10: trapped by Sirrus and Achenar
column11: the villains of Myst
column12: in the age of J'nanin (also the game's hub world). This character manages to escape and steals an important linking book from Atrus. The game consists of a hub world
column13: three ages
column14: and a final puzzle which takes place in a self-contained age.  The game's strength is that like Myst and Riven it has exceptionally good visual design (I have posted a few dozen screenshots if you want to check) and solid
column15: challenging but not impossible puzzles. If there's a weakness
column16: it's that to me the three main puzzle ages do not feel like cohesive world
column17: written so that characters could visit or live in them. There is a plot reason for this: the ages were written by Atrus as "tutorials" to explain how to build a world to his sons. But this gives them a sort of weird
column18: artificial quality where it is unclear why they are assembled the way they are or what a visitor might hope to get from them. Something I love about Myst and Riven is how the puzzles feel organic and integrated into the world
column19: but the world still feels livable
column20: and I didn't find that here.  The game's final climax makes use of a puzzle that I found interesting. It is easy but fun if you understand what makes it tick
column21: but maddening if you don't make the logical leap to figure out how it works. As with every Myst game
column22: take notes
column23: read the journals you find
column24: and listen to the voice acting. It is easy to miss things. I took around 7 pages of notes. Although I hadn't taken notes that were used specifically in the final puzzle
column25: my memory of certain clues found earlier did prompt me to understand the puzzle. I may have benefitted from playing the game in 3-4 marathon sessions over a few day period. I remembered virtually nothing from the game from my previous attempt to play it 15 years ago
column26: and the 7.4 hours it took me is the amount of time it took to finish the game and view the alternate "bad" endings. In general
column27: I would say this game is less difficult than Myst and Riven
column28: but not necessarily easy.  I want to make special note of the game's score. The first two games
column29: scored by Robyn Miller
column30: used ambient
column31: natural music. Here
column32: Jack Wall does soaring and often eastern-sounding score. It's a different approach. I like Miller's version more
column33: but Wall is still a very talented composer.  In terms of whether this is a good port -- it is a good but bare bones port. The game works on my computer without a hitch. Everything visually looked good and not stretched or janky. There is obviously some clash between the FMVs and the pre-rendered backgrounds
column34: but in general I thought everything looked great. Navigation was quick and easy
column35: and I didn't run into any timing issues that sometimes plague running old games on modern machines. Cyan worked with the crew at ResidualVM (a 3d spinoff of ScummVM) to make sure the ResidualVM engine fully supports the game's content. There are at the time of my writing no achievements
column36: trading cards
column37: or support for anything fancy
column38: and the visuals definitely showed some age. But I don't think this should discourage anyone from buying the port.  As with any Myst game
column39: good luck solving the puzzles and please try to resist the modern urge to immediately seek a hint. Walk around
column40: play with objects you find
column41: take a break
column42: come back to the game
column43: and if you find you get to the end
column44: you'll feel tremendously satisfied about the breakthroughs you've made.  I am really happy to see the entire Myst series under Cyan Worlds' ownership and published on Steam for people to play. I had a great time playing the game
column45: and although it did not make as strong of an impression as Myst and Riven did
column46: I'm confident that if you liked those two games

The Room Two (note: not based on the films The Room or Room!) is a point and click puzzle game that will be familiar to anyone who has played a room escape video game or done a live action room escape. If you've never played the original game The Room
column4: you should go buy and play that instead of looking at this one. For the rest of the review
column5: I assume that readers have played The Room.  In contrast to the Room where you were unpacking an elaborate toy box
column6: piece by piece
column7: the Room Two is something closer to a traditional room escape. Scenes contain multiple benches
column8: stations
column9: or objects you can interact with
column10: and keys or buttons from one can be used to activate things in another. You start with a room where everything is locked off
column11: and slowly you managed to wiggle into all the various items and stations. I'm not sure that I liked this better than the Room because I felt like I spent more time going from place to place
column12: orienting myself instead of actually solving puzzles.  The game is slightly longer than The Room
column13: maybe 30-45 minutes longer
column14: and definitely bigger budget with more interactivity and more going on. The story layer is also slightly thicker
column15: but still mostly just about setting a mood rather than a narrative or characters you'll care about.  As with the Room
column16: the game has an excellent hint system which helps keep the pace up by allowing you to make progress if you feel jammed. I recommend using hints if you feel stuck. My one complaint about the hints is that sometimes hints seem to emphasize bits you've already figured out
column17: forcing you to wait to actually get a hint for what to do now.  As with the first PC port

column3: 8.5/10  Pros; Amazing combat Great Soundtrack Lots of weapons and armour 9 classes that have different abilities Solid bosses (Especially the final boss) Bitterblack Isle is very fun to traverse and extremely challenging  Cons; Lack of enemy variety Lose pawns when they die (Can be one-shot by enemies such as Death) Rift Crystals don't drop enough so you have to rely on other players using your pawn Climbing on enemies can be frustrating Pawn A.I. can be hit and miss sometimes (Mostly fine though) Menu is quite annoying to navigate The stamina system results in your journeys lasting longer than they should  Overall this is an amazing game even if it does have a few issues.

column3: Loved Dungeon Defenders 1 and so far this one has been better in every regard. My only complaint so far is that it takes so long to hatch an egg and they are filling my inventory.  ~Edit~  It would be cool if the classes had secondary weapons to give them a bit more variety. Such as bringing back the crossbow to the huntress with a faster fire rate than the bow but lower damage per shot or a two handed weapon for the squire forgoing his shield in favor of a charged attack.  The individual construction gems is a nice feature but also a burden when you're playing with pre-constructed teams. A prime example is I often play with a group of my friends and enjoy playing hero spec'd huntress and squire where they enjoy playing tower spec'd monk and apprentice. When we complete a wave I have to go gather up my gems from the chest and drop them for my friends to use since they will have the much stronger buildings. It'd be a nice if I could pass my chest off to the other players automatically splitting the resources among the other players or having a feature for private rooms to allow one person to gather all of the gems from the chest they open.  I would also love an endless mode where you just try to survive an endless amount of waves.  The new tavern is nice and actually feels more like a social place rather than just a hub for in between levels.

Nothing but a paid DLC platform.  Developer officially dropped support less than 1 year after launch. All sorts of errors and bugs they refuse to address. Only pushed out paid DLC patches. Forced paid DLC whether you buy it or not in your game with no ability to disable it. Completely imbalanced units and factions part of paid DLC to encourage players to buy it so they can use it as well.  False modding support. Modding is severly limited to adjust predefined values. Cannot mod basic things on models such as transparency thus no custom models what so ever. You can barely recolor models.  DirectX12 support is still beta. It will never leave beta. Unit shadows have been completely bugged out and won't display unless you view them from a very limited viewing angle which makes the game look awful. CA refuses to address it dodging players that bring it up.

column3: Typical pay-2-win game.  Leveling = stat increases.  Gear = stat increases.  Free-2-play = being non competitive fodder for players that pay.  Super grindy to encourage players to buy and buy micro transactions.  Visual customization very limited and poorly done.   If you're looking for any enjoyable game this isn't it. If you're looking for a competitive multiplayer this game isn't it. If you're looking to have huge advantages over other players via spending money this game is for you.   Games looks like something from the PlayStation 2 but it also runs poorly.

The biggest attraction of this game is that it’s made for the PC and not just some multi platform paid DLC by the numbers modern game. That is instantly apparent when you load it up. This game launched without a ridiculous season pass or any mention of paid DLC. There is no horrid crafting that now plagues seemingly every game in existence. This game is like a time capsule when games were made by gamers and everything wasn’t designed for paste eating illiterate console gamers. The UI is stylish and uses the whole screen. You actually get an inventory and sorting features and you don’t have to click 15 times to bring up a comparison between gear.   There are no nerdy data logs sitting everywhere explaining the lore of how elves take a dump in the woods. There are things you can read if you want but these are interesting or relevant to where they are such as a note from a dead person next to their corpse. It’s not some primer on the organization of the ruling council of the nerd kingdom you’ll never come across in the game. This brings up one of the greatest strengths on this game as it doesn’t try to overwhelm you with nerd lore. Dialogue makes sense and isn’t boring nerd explanations. This is made even better by the excellent voice acting in which you won’t be cringing over even if the character is swearing. Did I mention that The White Wolf himself is one of the main character voice? That doesn’t hurt either.   I like this game. It reminds me of the good old days of PC gaming where everything wasn’t designed around trying to limit players to spend more money. I don’t feel the need to rush through the game or overthink the mechanics of the game. I can load it up
column4: feel like I’m in a fantasy world
column5: and care about the story because your not trying to do 15 different fetch quests to get 10 pig butts in order to craft a shield.   Good old PC RPG game. There is loot. No tedious crafting. Numerous different enemies based around traditional fantasy tropes.  When you buy and sell things at a merchant the UI is simple and straight forward. You can compare items easily and there is only one currency. The game isn’t a pretentious nerd fest is what I’m saying. If you like fantasy RPG games you’ll probably like this. The RTS elements isn’t the main focus of the game and the campaign doesn’t just plop you on maps to destroy the other side to proceed to the next map.

column8: 2nd best being the pistol and the stun gun being the 3rd with its ability to incapcitate (most) foes. You should be aware this game has denuvo
column9: however that never affected me in any of my 40 hours of gameplay. The only thing that affected me was stuttering that used to happen as i suspect a memory leak when the game has been open too long..this was easily solved by just quicksaving then restarting the game..im hoping this will get fixed in a future patch.  The combat is very interesting
column10: as most times there is a way to sneak past your foes or simply outmanuveur them when investing in the mobility tree or just fight them head on
column11: whichever style you pick will work. Which brings me to the upgrade system
column12: you use neuromods to give yourself a flat damage
column13: hp or more inventory space..these neuromods can be found plentifully around the game and eventually crafted.  However
column14: you can also invest the typhoid (alien) abilities which can be very fun and really useful in areas where you might not have access to traditionally with keycards.   I will have to say one thing..fortified turrets are op...have 4 of them bad boys lined up and nothing will make it past..even nightmares get shredded provided you throw a nullifier grenade.  If you are a fan of very good single player games and has plenty of exploration and at your own pace type gameplay...this game is definitely for you. The atmosphere is fantastic and it really gives the feeling of a broken space station that has been mostly void of life besides you and a handful of survivors. The game runs incredibly well on my rig (see profile).  Just 1 more thing
column15: if you do the last mission that involves meeting up with alex yu
column16: it triggers aliens that will block most of the entrances on the map which in turn makes it mostly impossible to carry out non story objectives..just something to think about since i made that mistake and couldnt complete a few side story objectives.  My final thoughts are that this game is definitely one of the best single player experiences I've had in 2017 with alot of content. If you were to do all side story quests you could easily get 40+ hours out of this game which at 30 euros is very good value for money.

column3: An amazing FPS with a focus on quick and seamless slaughtering of demons. Its also very well optimised..I get framerates between 150-200 (GTX 1070) on average..with 200 being the limit. Its smooth and definitely a pc game you should consider picking up as it goes on sale regularly for 15-20 euro.  If your thinking of a good single player campaign game..this game is definitely for you..although there is multiplayer..this game is definitely more focused on delivering a good single player experience and it does whole heartedly. Firstly I got the base game for free during a steam special for it. Or maybe a ubisoft one. but i have now purchased the season pass 2017 and the marching fire dlc
column4: not out yet as i write.  second
column5: i play this game with xbox one controller. my review should be read in with that in mind.  this game i wish i had gotten round to install earlier; what stopped me was
column6: i looked at the minimum specs and my 960m gpu in the laptop is 15% or so below. however i installed it just to see
column7: and enjoyed it.  the game has a single player story in 3 stages; one for each knights
column8: samurai and vikings. the story isnt bad
column9: and not a token campaign as much as say CoD games. but mp is where this game is seeming aimed. mp is cross platform from what i read in game explanations.  the combat system can seem complicated
column10: but is actually easier than it seemed at first. what was seeming complex is the lock on guard system which allows you to take one of 3 stances (one character in the story has a 4th) to match your enemy. this allows you to parry a blow from an enemy in the same stance. then you have a light (faster) blow
column11: and heavy (slower) blow. those are the basics. the idea is to hit them when in a different stance
column12: so they cant block and not get hit first. you dont need to be in a guard stance to attack though. there is a UI thing to show which stance the enemy is in and it goes red when they launch an attack. obviously you can also tell guard by looking at their weapon position.  on top
column13: you have various other combinations of button presses for other moves which you can examine in the pause menu moveset. these include break guard moves
column14: unblockable sweeping heavy moves
column15: a heavy feint even. while it can seem frustrating with some bosses in the story
column16: there is a satisfaction when you pull off a move right.  there are also abilities. in the story mode you can pick only two
column17: and have a third you can pick up from the field such as a banner that gives health regen to nearby allies and you
column18: or a catapult strike for example. in the mp side
column19: you can have four. these abilities also level up like yourself with use.  mp: i think ubisoft did something clever here. in mp all your fights affect a campaign for which you have to pick a faction at the start
column20: these last for a couple of weeks. at the end you get rewards of loot based on faction performance. then there are battles which end in hours which your fights are part of. you can see the current ones on the war map.  but additionally
column21: ubisoft realised that some people wont be all that good against other players - so i notice you can also play against AI instead
column22: at least in some modes. you can also make a custom game to do this
column23: but you cant level up in custom games
column24: but they are good for practise. so i can set up a skirmish

I'm not going to repeat anything any other review site already said. Evolve is a unique
column4: well-designed
column5: balanced
column6: gorgeous
column7: and sometimes inconsistent experience. At it's best
column8: with a great group of people
column9: it's amazing. At it's worst
column10: it can be downright boring and frustrating dealing with players who don't communicate or can't play their role effectively. Go and read any other professional review for details.  What I'm going to stress however
column11: is the overreaction people seem to have on the whole DLC issue. I'll put it in points to clarify certain things that people seem to be complaining about
column12: unfounded or otherwise.  - Is there day one DLC?  YES. Skins. Just skins. Do they effect the game in any way that gives players who buy it an advantage? NO. Are they forcing you to buy it? NO. So why are you complaining? You don't like it
column13: don't buy it. No need to moan about how it's 'supposed' to be in the game.  - Is the game worth the full price tag? Yes
column14: in no way does the base game feel incomplete
column15: or that there is anything that was 'purposely left out' to later be cashed in as DLC. You get a fully competent
column16: balanced
column17: mostly glitch-free game for your money
column18: which is more than I can say for most AAA titles recently.  - They already stated that they will be giving out future maps for FREE. This is something that pretty much no other modern online shooter is doing. Games like COD
column19: Battlefield and the like
column20: release new maps that you need to purchase
column21: otherwise you can't play with a certain group of players. With Evolve
column22: the player base is not split based on the purchase of DLC. Anyone can play with or against anyone
column23: regardless if they decided to pay up for more content.  - NO
column24: the extra hunters and monsters aren't already done and being 'purposely held back' to be cashed in sometime in the future. If you follow the development process
column25: this extra content isn't even close to being done. Stop saying that they're trying to milk you for more money.  However
column26: I do agree with certain complaints  - The pricing for the DLC is downright ridiculous. Skins shouldn't cost that much. But again
column27: nobody is forcing you to buy them
column28: and in no way do they give players an unfair advantage.  - The 'season pass' does not contain all of the future content
column29: which can be confusing and frustrating. This I find to be absurd
column30: when a season pass usually means that it should allow you access to all the DLC that will be released. They should really reconsider the contents of the pass.  - The way the different packages of the game are being promoted is downright confusing. This I understand why it drew the ire of quite a number of people.  In conclusion
column31: although the way the DLC is being marketed isn't perfect
column32: most of the hate people seem to be giving it is largely exaggerated. Evolve is a great game
column33: and poor marketing shouldn't deter you from diving into a truly unique experience. Just be a smarter consumer and do some research on the DLC options if you have your doubts.

column3: Если честно я и не думал что данная игра может хоть как то зацепить меня..Но она действительно стоит своих денег. В NieR:Automata много плюсов но и минусы тоже есть. Огромный минус этой игры так это однообразие...просто иногда скучно бить одних и тех же мобов и бегать по тем же локациям. Вообщем что можно сказать:Покупаем и играем))  (Редактирую) Сегодня перепрошел на все концовки и был удивлен...Сюжет все таки реально достойный для создания аниме или фильма.Особенно конец (Е) Просто без слов...После я пожертвовал всеми сохранениями для помощи другим игрокам...Эх как же это классно..Буду проходить заного и не пожалею об потраченном времени.) Всем спасибо и удачной игры.

column5: my opinion of Skyrim is very mixed
column6: because it has both pros and cons. Let me elaborate.  On the positive side of things
column7: Skyrim improves greatly on its predecessors in a lot of ways. Many things are more streamlined or made more consistent
column8: you get a lot more combat options
column9: spells are more unique
column10: and you have the addition of more unique combat encounters in the form of dragons. Radiant quests also make sure you always have something to do
column11: but that brings me to my negative points...  Questlines and characters are
column12: with the exception of the Daedric quests
column13: flat and uninspired. Nothing you do - no matter what the dialogue may imply - has ANY considerable or lasting effect on the world
column14: and that makes it hard to motivate yourself in the end game
column15: when you're so overpowered that combat is a butchering at best and a slap fight at worst. That's not the only negative
column16: either - but the other negatives deserve a paragraph of their own
column17: considering recent decisions from Bethesda and Valve.  The game is exceedingly glitchy and buggy. On top of that
column18: most of the pros I mentioned are only potential pros
column19: that need a lot of polish to actually lend positivity to the game. This used to be a non-issue thanks to mods - but now
column20: Valve is pushing for modders to put their work behind a paywall. This creates a TON of new issues: fixing game problems can now cost money. And if incompatible mods create a bug
column21: you might have just wasted money
column22: or worse have to spend additional money to fix it. You may argue that this won't happen to all mods
column23: but consider that sharing resources between modders will become exceedingly rare now that profits are involved. This whole fiasco of a train wreck is essentially a microcosm of everything that's wrong with modern capitalism. Plus
column24: one mod that EVERYONE considers essential (in fact
column25: a lot of mods require it)
column26: SkyUI
column27: is already going P2P.  Honestly
column28: at this rate
column29: I'd really recommend buying Morrowind or Oblivion instead. Or
column30: hell
column31: I'd recommend Elder Scrolls Online over this. At least that game is fully functional without potentially requiring additional purchases.

column3: Now this.....is classic :)
So after playing this game for almost 6 years (Keep in mind
column4: This isn't my first account and I did got the game actually back on it's first week of release in 2012) But anyway
column5: It's time to be honest and show my actual opinion about the game at the current state (As of April 2018). CS GO was something very special to me as this was the first game to show me the competitive side of many different games and gave me the courage to transition from games like CoD and BF and pretty much became a part of me overtime as it made me to think differently about the way that games can be played but as some people say "All good things must come to an end!" isn't? Here it ends.  As the time passed on. We can see that Valve barely supports the game and this can be noticed by the lack of proper updates to the game and less listening to it's community. The promise in 2017 for the Panorama UI? It's almost mid 2018 and still nothing about it The matchmaking being at it's worst state like it's never been like before Lack of new maps and operations
column6: Some of you may remember that we had 2-3 operations a year? Now we are barely getting only 1 a year (That's if we are lucky enough to get). 5vs5 unranked matchmaking (With a sort of hidden Normal MMR)? Nope The option to play on official MM with 128tick? Nope
column7: Rely on 3rd party services to do so No Server selection? Come on Valve
column8: Even Dota2 does that... And I can continue with the list but why I should do it? You already got the point I guess so.  Overall
column9: I still would be playing CS from time to time but however. I cannot recommend this game anymore for new players at the current state. I really hope that Valve would take some things into consideration and would improve over time. It was fun while it lasted but not anymore.

column3: People are going to ask me "Dude
column4: How the hell you can review this game when you got less than 100 hours?" and I actually can understand you at some point but this is my first impression from the game.  As the time passed on
column5: I pretty much got bored of playing CS GO all the time and really wanted to find a new game that based on similar concept and my friend told me "You really should try R6S"
column6: For sure
column7: CS GO is not the same as R6S but they pretty much got one thing in common. It requires a lot of strategy and teamwork in order to win matches.  Gameplay : By my own experience. Most of the time. The gameplay was feeling kinda slow but that's how it's supposed to be I guess as this game requires strategy and careful planning or you pretty much going to die and you know that you did a huge mistake and as a result you got punished by the game.But at the same time it feels rewarding since you learning from it and trying not to do the same thing again.  Community : I have already experienced lots of toxicity and many other things from different games that I'm playing at the moment such as CS GO
column8: Overwatch and League of Legends and I thought it would be quite the same on R6S as well. Well
column9: I was actually really surprised. Now of course nobody is going to avoid toxicity since people with anger management issues would play the game and I have met some toxic people on this game but most of the time I have got matched with people who actually know how to play the game and also being very helpful for the new players. You know how good it is to meet people who act as human beings after coming back from a game with toxic people?  Graphics and optimization : When I hear that a game is made by Ubisoft
column10: My thought is going to be "Ohh damn
column11: another broken game with lots of performance issues" but it was really far away from what I thought. I'm playing on i7 4790 and GTX 1070 on the Maxed out settings (With the Ultra HD textures as well) with the T-AA and indeed can maintain above 144FPS without any problem and the game indeed looks well  In conclusion
column12: I really looking forward to keep playing this game in the future and would try a bit the competitive match-making really soon (Would update the review about it later on) and have to say that Ubisoft did here a great job with the game and indeed improved it overtime and kudos to the devlopers of the game about it! I can without any doubt recommend this game for people who are looking for a strategic game that they can enjoy for a long time.  Competitive MM : It took quite some time for me to decide how the MM is
column13: Each game has it's own flaws but the MM does have some really serious issues that make the competitive mode to look like a joke and yes
column14: I'm mostly talking about leavers. The penalties are pretty much worthless and doesn't do anything in order to prevent players from leaving the matches. 15 minutes for each penalty (May be fine for the first cooldown) isn't enough by any means. And some matches can be frustrating not because of a poor teamwork but when you have to start the game as 4vs5 or even worse in some games. When a person disconnects in the first round. it should offer to the team the option (Like a remake that exists on LoL) if they want to continue the match or shut it down and only the leaver would get a lose. But when everything is going as it should be (Getting a great teammates or going with your premades)
column15: Then indeed the competitive is worth it and can provide a lot of great time.  Overall rating : 8/10 18/1/2018: Added "Competitive MM" (Sorry if it looks like a rant)

column3: Awesome little game. At first I thought I had changed a language setting somehow  but soon realised that this game portrayed it's meaning of words using the expressions and gestures of the characters. It has a very interesting use of the controller and it takes a little while to get used to controlling the two brothers. This really is a great experience. My hand has never felt so alone.
